item.description:
jaglazier posted a photo:

View from the tower roof. The castle of Obidos was turned into a luxury hotel already in 1951, the Pousada Castelo De Obidos. It's a bit dated and musty, but full of character. Obidos, Portugal. Copyright 2026, James A. Glazier

item.title: Barbaresco: a village among the vineyards
item.description:
presbi posted a photo:

Barbaresco is a municipality in the Province of Cuneo in the Italian region Piedmont, located about 50 kilometres (31 mi) southeast of Turin and about 60 kilometres (37 mi) northeast of Cuneo. Barbaresco is principally known for its homonymous medieval tower, constructed between the 12th and 14th centuries, Barbaresco Castle, and its production of wine bearing the same name

Barbaresco, along with the Langhe-Roero and Monferrato wine-growing area, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Many thanks to everyone who will pass by visiting my shots. Comments are appreciated. You are welcome. Sergio

¬© Sergio Presbitero 2026, All Rights Reserved

item.title: The Snowy Miracle of Georgia
item.description:
onezashvili posted a photo:

Gurjaani Kvelatsminda stands as an architectural beacon amidst the lush vineyards of Gurjaani Town in the Kakheti region of Georgia. Setting itself apart with two equally-sized octagonal domes, this 8th-century cathedral offers a rare glimpse into a distinctive period of Georgian architecture.
item.author: nobody@flickr.com (onezashvili)
item.media:title: The Snowy Miracle of Georgia
item.media:description: Gurjaani Kvelatsminda stands as an architectural beacon amidst the lush vineyards of Gurjaani Town in the Kakheti region of Georgia. Setting itself apart with two equally-sized octagonal domes, this 8th-century cathedral offers a rare glimpse into a distinctive period of Georgian architecture.

item.title: Vineyards Among Historic Mining
item.description:
Stuart Grieve NZ posted a photo:

This area near Cromwell was heavily mined for gold from the 1860's on, particularly hydraulic sluicing which greatly altered the remaining landscape. It's a good area for grapes however, so much of the sluiced area is now producing wine.
item.author: nobody@flickr.com (Stuart Grieve NZ)
item.media:title: Vineyards Among Historic Mining
item.media:description: This area near Cromwell was heavily mined for gold from the 1860's on, particularly hydraulic sluicing which greatly altered the remaining landscape. It's a good area for grapes however, so much of the sluiced area is now producing wine.

item.title: Die Rochuskapelle / The Rochus Chapel
item.description:
kundeg2 posted a photo:

Die Rochuskapelle in Nittel ‚Äì stiller Ort √ºber den Weinbergen, mit weitem Blick √ºber die Mosel und die luxemburgische Landschaft. Die Rochuskapelle in Nittel ist dem heiligen Rochus gewidmet, der als Schutzpatron gegen Seuchen und Krankheiten verehrt wird. Die Kapelle steht f√ºr Hoffnung, Schutz und Dankbarkeit und war √ºber Jahrhunderte ein Ort des Gebets in Zeiten von Not und Epidemien. Ihre Lage √ºber den Weinbergen unterstreicht den Charakter als stiller R√ºckzugs- und Andachtsort mit weiter Sicht √ºber das Moseltal.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Rochus Chapel in Nittel ‚Äì a quiet place above the vineyards, offering wide views over the Moselle and the Luxembourg countryside.
The Rochus Chapel in Nittel is dedicated to Saint Roch, venerated as a protector against plague and illness. It symbolizes hope, protection, and gratitude, and for centuries served as a place of prayer during times of hardship and epidemics. Its elevated position above the vineyards emphasizes its role as a place of reflection, overlooking the Moselle Valley. (Quelle/source: Internet)

Vielen herzlichen Dank allen f√ºr die Ansichten, wertsch√§tzenden Kommentare und Favoriten zu dem Foto, ich freue mich sehr dar√ºber! / Many thanks to everyone for viewing, commenting and faving the photograph, it's very much appreciated!
item.author: nobody@flickr.com (kundeg2)

item.title: Cristo Rei na Serra da Marofa: Um S√≠mbolo de F√© na Paisagem
item.description:
vmribeiro.net posted a photo:

No topo da Serra da Marofa, a cerca de 977 metros de altitude, ergue-se o Cristo Rei, principal marco visual do concelho de Figueira de Castelo Rodrigo, no distrito da Guarda. Inaugurada em meados do s√©culo XX por iniciativa local, esta escultura em pedra integra um percurso de via-sacra com pequenas capelas, usado em romarias e peregrina√ß√µes ao longo do ano. A partir do miradouro junto ao monumento domina‚Äëse o planalto do Riba‚ÄëC√¥a e o Douro Superior; em dias l√≠mpidos, o horizonte estende‚Äëse √† raia de Castela e aos relevos da Serra da Estrela, evidenciando a import√¢ncia estrat√©gica desta eleva√ß√£o. A paisagem em redor revela um mosaico agr√≠cola mediterr√¢nico, com vinhas, amendoais e manchas de pinhal, que testemunham a longa ocupa√ß√£o humana e a economia rural da Beira Interior. A proximidade da aldeia hist√≥rica de Castelo Rodrigo refor√ßa a leitura do local como varanda sobre o territ√≥rio fronteiri√ßo portugu√™s, onde patrim√≥nio religioso, mem√≥ria hist√≥rica e observa√ß√£o da paisagem se articulam num mesmo cen√°rio.

The Santa Cruz Tower stands on the cliff above Santa Cruz Beach, in the parish of Silveira, municipality of Torres Vedras, and is the most recognizable feature of the local seafront. Built in the mid-20th century on the initiative of Jos√© Pedro de Oliveira, it is part of the tradition of Portuguese seaside resorts that marked the tourist occupation of the coast from the end of the 19th century onwards. Its revivalist design, with arcades on the lower floor and crenellated crown, recalls the style of historic watchtowers, now reappropriated as a viewpoint over the Atlantic and a landmark for those walking along the promenade. At its base, the building connects with the seawall, the stairs, and the terraces that line the beach, combining leisure, beach support, and coastal protection functions. This setting reflects the coexistence of coastal engineering, public use of the territory, and heritage enhancement of the landscape. The tower, often associated with the tourist image of Santa Cruz, thus synthesizes the relationship between architecture, geography, and contemporary beach practices.
item.author: nobody@flickr.com (vmribeiro.net)

Inaugurada em meados do s√©culo XX por iniciativa local, esta escultura em pedra integra um percurso de via-sacra com pequenas capelas, usado em romarias e peregrina√ß√µes ao longo do ano. A partir do miradouro junto ao monumento domina‚Äëse o planalto do Riba‚ÄëC√¥a e o Douro Superior; em dias l√≠mpidos, o horizonte estende‚Äëse √† raia de Castela e aos relevos da Serra da Estrela, evidenciando a import√¢ncia estrat√©gica desta eleva√ß√£o. A paisagem em redor revela um mosaico agr√≠cola mediterr√¢nico, com vinhas, amendoais e manchas de pinhal, que testemunham a longa ocupa√ß√£o humana e a economia rural da Beira Interior. A proximidade da aldeia hist√≥rica de Castelo Rodrigo refor√ßa a leitura do local como varanda sobre o territ√≥rio fronteiri√ßo portugu√™s, onde patrim√≥nio religioso, mem√≥ria hist√≥rica e observa√ß√£o da paisagem se articulam num mesmo cen√°rio.

The Santa Cruz Tower stands on the cliff above Santa Cruz Beach, in the parish of Silveira, municipality of Torres Vedras, and is the most recognizable feature of the local seafront. Built in the mid-20th century on the initiative of Jos√© Pedro de Oliveira, it is part of the tradition of Portuguese seaside resorts that marked the tourist occupation of the coast from the end of the 19th century onwards. Its revivalist design, with arcades on the lower floor and crenellated crown, recalls the style of historic watchtowers, now reappropriated as a viewpoint over the Atlantic and a landmark for those walking along the promenade. At its base, the building connects with the seawall, the stairs, and the terraces that line the beach, combining leisure, beach support, and coastal protection functions. This setting reflects the coexistence of coastal engineering, public use of the territory, and heritage enhancement of the landscape. The tower, often associated with the tourist image of Santa Cruz, thus synthesizes the relationship between architecture, geography, and contemporary beach practices.
